results.title: The Event of the political party
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: One of four films in the “Mass communications and society” series forming a case study on British politics and television, shot during the 1976 Labour and Conservative Party conferences held in Blackpool and Brighton respectively. Concentrates on the live broadcasts of the events of each day and reveals the philosophies that guide the broadcasters in their decision making. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Eternal forest
results.brief_description: Designed to explain the important part played by forests in paper manufacture. Photographed in the Boola-Boola area of Gippsland, Victoria, various operations are shown in which timber, removed for papermaking, is being replaced by seedling pines which will mature for use in future years. The film includes views of the residential area of Traralgon, the manufacturing processes at the Maryvale mill, and also lists various uses of paper products.

results.title: The Eternal forest
results.creator_credit: U.S.A Department of Agriculture and United States. Forest Service
results.brief_description: The story of North America’s primeval forests showing early neglect in the years of America’s growth and expansion, as opposed to today’s sensible balance between the use of forest resources and their protection for future generations

results.title: The Eternal fight
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas, Michael Alexander, Madeleine Carroll Films and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: Through history humans have fought an eternal struggle against plagues, hunger, and war. Scientists of many nations have contributed to this fight against disease. The developments of the 19th and 20th centuries havce created new health problems because of industrial employment, crowded cities and more rapid means of communication. Control of disease is only now possible on a world-wide basis. The film is a dramatised story of the work of the World Health Organisation organsied to fight disease on a global scale.

results.title: The Eskimo: fight for life
results.creator_credit: Robert Young, Quentin Brown and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An authentic record of the life of the Netsilik Inuit of the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic during their last migratory camp. It shows the old Inuit culture, the communal life of the seal hunters and their families, their complete adaptation to the environment. This film was produced, with commentary from footage brought out of the Arctic by anthropologists. (Award: New York)

results.title: The Environment: garbage
results.brief_description: Uses a montage of garbage cans, music and images, with no narration, to reveal the many kinds of garbage and the need to be aware of the problem. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Environment game
results.creator_credit: Michael Blakstad and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: Technological progress, essential to the economy of an industrial nation, must be subject to checks and controls to prevent the destruction of landscapes and pollution of the quality of life. Using schoolchildren to represent the various interests concerned, the film debates the problems, with visits to various locations to illustrate the issues at stake.

results.title: The Environment (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course looks at the way the international economic community is tackling the issue of environmental protection. Since the late 1970s there has been a growing concern, especially by communities in wealthier nations, over the high environmental cost of unrestricted economic development. Developing countries, however, have argued that trade restrictions predicated on environmental law offer unfair economic advantages to richer nations. In the first half of the program we look at the example of the Mexican tuna industry which has come under fire because of the destruction of dolphin life. However when the United States attempted to place an embargo on Mexican tuna, the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade (GATT) ruled that this was contrary to the principles of Free Trade. In the second half we look at the destruction of Europe’s Rhine River by industrial pollution. The panel of economists examining both issues discuss some of the implications for trade if environmental law becomes institutionalised in the global economy.

results.title: The Enlightenment

results.title: The English language: story of its development
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the English language from its roots in the Anglo and Saxon tongues, through its infusion of French and Latin, and finally its emergence as a printed language which is still growing and changing. The influence of Church monks, William the Conqueror, Chaucer and Shakespeare are discussed.
